'Mariner 4' (together with Mariner 3 known as 'MarinerâMars 1964') was the
fourth in a series of spacecraft intended for planetary exploration in a flyby
mode. It was designed to conduct closeup scientific observations of Mars and to
transmit these observations to Earth. Launched on November 28, 1964, {{cite web
 | url = http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1964-077A
 | title = Mariner 4 work = NSSDC Master Catalog publisher = NASA accessdate =
 | 2009-02-11
}} Mariner 4 performed the first successful flyby of the planet Mars
returning the first pictures of the Martian surface. It captured the first
images of another planet ever returned from deep space; their depiction of a
cratered, seemingly dead world largely changed the view of the scientific
community on life on Mars. {{cite web
 | url = http://home.earthlink.net/~nbrass1/mariner/miv.htm title = Mariner IV -
 | First Flyby of Mars: Some personal experiences last = Momsen first = Bill
 | year = 2006 page = 1 accessdate = 2009-02-11
}} {{cite web
 | url = http://home.earthlink.net/~nbrass1/mariner/miv-2.htm title = Mariner IV
 | - First Flyby of Mars: Some personal experiences last = Momsen first = Bill
 | year = 2006 page = 2 accessdate = 2009-02-11
}} Other mission objectives were to perform field and particle
measurements in interplanetary space in the vicinity of Mars and to provide
experience in and knowledge of the engineering capabilities for interplanetary
flights of long duration. On December 21, 1967 communications with Mariner 4
were terminated.
